content.full_text: The classification defines 'multiple' as involving two or more sites. Follow chapter-specific guidelines for assigning codes for 'multiple sites.' In the absence of chapter-specific guidelines, assign codes describing specified sites individually when documented. When the specified site(s) are not documented, assign the appropriate code for 'multiple sites.' (Evidence: pg no: 19, L35-L38)
content.summary: Guidelines for coding conditions involving multiple anatomical sites, including when to use specific site codes versus multiple site codes (Evidence: pg no: 19, L35-L38)
key_concepts: Multiple is defined as involving two or more sites (Evidence: pg no: 19, L36)
Chapter-specific guidelines take priority for multiple sites coding (Evidence: pg no: 19, L36-L37)
Individual site codes used when sites are documented (Evidence: pg no: 19, L37-L38)
Multiple sites codes used when specific sites not documented (Evidence: pg no: 19, L38)

detailed_rules.rule_text: The classification defines 'multiple' as involving two or more sites (Evidence: pg no: 19, L36)
detailed_rules.explanation: For coding purposes, multiple sites means any condition affecting two or more anatomical locations (Evidence: pg no: 19, L36)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Follow chapter-specific guidelines for assigning codes for 'multiple sites' (Evidence: pg no: 19, L36-L37)
detailed_rules.explanation: When available, chapter-specific guidelines override general multiple sites coding rules (Evidence: pg no: 19, L36-L37)

detailed_rules.rule_text: In the absence of chapter-specific guidelines, assign codes describing specified sites individually when documented (Evidence: pg no: 19, L37-L38)
detailed_rules.explanation: When specific anatomical sites are documented and no chapter-specific guidance exists, code each site separately (Evidence: pg no: 19, L37-L38)

detailed_rules.rule_text: When the specified site(s) are not documented, assign the appropriate code for 'multiple sites' (Evidence: pg no: 19, L38)
detailed_rules.explanation: Use multiple sites codes when documentation does not specify individual anatomical locations (Evidence: pg no: 19, L38)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Determine if condition involves two or more sites
Step 2: Check for chapter-specific guidelines for multiple sites coding
Step 3: If chapter-specific guidelines exist, follow them
Step 4: If no chapter-specific guidelines, check if specific sites are documented
Step 5: If sites documented, assign individual site codes
Step 6: If sites not documented, assign multiple sites code

code_patterns.description: Codes designated for conditions affecting multiple anatomical sites (Evidence: pg no: 19, L38)
code_patterns.example: Codes ending in .9 or designated as 'multiple sites'
code_patterns.explanation: Used when specific sites are not documented or when chapter guidelines specify their use

Step 2: Note that specific sites are not documented
Step 4: Assign appropriate multiple sites code

correct_coding.rationale: Specific sites not documented, so multiple sites code is appropriate (Evidence: pg no: 19, L38)

Code individual sites when specifically documented (Evidence: pg no: 19, L37-L38)
tips: Multiple means two or more sites (Evidence: pg no: 19, L36)
